top_categories.workout_context: The Rad Dirt Fest rewards athletes who can hold sustained power without blowing up — threshold is the engine that drives everything above Zone 2.
The Rad Dirt Fest’s high-desert gravel with long sustained climbs and competitive field demand explosive aerobic capacity — the ability to respond to surges without blowing up.
Over-unders train the lactate clearance you’ll need at The Rad Dirt Fest when surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding hard.
The Rad Dirt Fest’s high-desert gravel, mesa terrain demands rapid power changes — surge over obstacles, settle on smoother sections, repeat for hours.
Racing The Rad Dirt Fest isn’t just fitness — it’s pacing, fueling, and executing when conditions deteriorate. This workout practices the race itself.
At 113 miles, The Rad Dirt Fest punishes athletes who haven’t trained their body to produce power when glycogen runs low.
The Rad Dirt Fest’s 10,613ft of climbing demands seated and standing versatility — the ability to change climbing style as gradient and fatigue dictate.
The G-Spot zone (88–92% FTP) is where you’ll spend the hardest sustained miles of The Rad Dirt Fest. Make this intensity feel like home.
Every session at The Rad Dirt Fest intensity builds on this aerobic foundation — the endurance base is the soil everything else grows in.
Critical power determines how long you can sustain above-threshold efforts at The Rad Dirt Fest — a higher CP means more time in the red before failure.
Low-cadence force work builds the muscular strength for The Rad Dirt Fest’s 10,613ft of climbing — especially the grinding, low-speed ascents.
Blended sessions combine endurance with intensity spikes — exactly what The Rad Dirt Fest’s high-desert gravel with long sustained climbs delivers on race day.

race_overlay.nutrition: Target 60–80g carbs/hour for The Rad Dirt Fest’s 113 miles. Start fueling within the first 30 minutes — early fueling prevents late-race collapse. Bonking at mile 60 is a nutrition failure, not a fitness failure.
race_overlay.altitude: The Rad Dirt Fest with 10,613ft of climbing, much of it above 8,000ft demands altitude preparation. Arrive 5–7 days early for acclimatization. Expect 5–15% power reduction at altitude. Increase iron intake 4 weeks out. Hydrate aggressively — altitude increases fluid loss by 20–40%. Altitude 6,000-9,000 ft.
race_overlay.terrain: Mixed terrain at The Rad Dirt Fest requires surface adaptability. Include weekly rides on high-desert gravel with long sustained climbs to build confidence. Expect: high-desert gravel, mesa terrain, long sustained climbs.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on TT Threshold, VO2max, and Over Under to prepare you for 113 miles of high-desert gravel with long sustained climbs in Trinidad, Colorado.
